This is a long review so if you want just a brief summary of why I recommend Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior skip to Results and read from there.RuneStorm brings to life all of our dreams by finally making a title where you get to see what happens after you play a game. After playing Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior you’ll learn that maybe you should reconsider before you go out of your way to break everything in a room.Story:Lo Wang got in a devastating battle at a temple nearby destroying everything in sight. You are hired as a janitor to clean up a terrible mess. Bodies are everywhere, art is destroyed, and you’re the only man for the job. Campaign:There is one level; it’s the same as the first level in the new Shadow Warrior game. It’s your job to clean it up with a mop and your hands. You must deposit the debris into various incinerators, mop up blood, and grab all the cash you can find. The campaign only has two achievements, clean up everything and grab all the money. If you can do this you’ve proven that “you’re the best around and nothing’s ever gonna to keep you down.”Gameplay:This game plays similar to an FPS. The camera is always in first person and your two weapons are a mop and your hands. You must pick up garbage with your hands and throw it into incinerators while mopping up gallons of blood. You better keep your mop clean, but beware for some odd reason the machines that provide water can shoot out an organ. Similar to a normal janitor after you are done you must clock out.Results:If you have always wondered what happens after a game, wonder what life as a janitor for crime scenes would be like, or even just want to play a game that doesn’t push your wits then Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior is for you. This brilliant game is hilarious to play if you just beat the first level of Shadow Warrior. For some odd reason the character sounds exactly like Lo Wang, which makes me wonder if after he saved the universe he decided to give up fighting and clean up his messes. Pros:+You get to experience Shadow Warrior through a whole new light.+You get to clean up bodies, mop up blood, and steal money… how many games offer that?+Good graphics+Easy gameplay, with simple controls.+Funny dialogue+Two straightforward achievements+Its free if you already own Shadow Warrior (2013)+YOU GET TO BE A JANITORCons:-Cleaning up everything achievement can be really annoying as a single bullet shell could be the culprit.-There is only one level (why can’t we clean more)

												Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior... OOOHH YOU WANNA CLEANUP SOME WANG?This game does something I thought nothing could ever do... It made cleaning your mess up fun. So as an employee of Zilla Corp. You are assigned to clean up the temple that was trashed in the beginning of Shadow Warrior, all the bodies, blood, and damn broken glass. You use your mop to clean up blood, the incinerator to burn the little bits, and the hazmat bins for the bigger stuff. Find some bloody money? Put it in the suitcase for an extra reward when you clock out... and maybe put a few priceless artifacts in there too. And why not use that dinky little device you received to make sure you didn’t miss anything? And remember, clean with honor. Wow, was it difficult to decide if I recommend this or not. It’s a cleaning game, so there’s defiantly going to be mixed opinions, for example a friend and I LOVE these Cleanup Detail games, while two of my other friends hate them, and I recommend on if I like a game or not, not if it's good or bad. So there were two ways I could review this, as a good game or as a bad game. I decided I’ll do it as a good game, because I sure as hell liked it.This, for being a cleaning game, is amazing. Somehow it makes cleaning addicting, I spent an hour just burning stuff and another cleaning up the blood... and I was okay with that!The visuals, as with Shadow Warrior’s, aren’t too great, but defiantly get the job done. Dialog is amazing with Wang’s witty comments as you burn stuff and find money.But this game is riddled with bugs and glitches. Sometimes when picking up an object, it sporadically flies through the air, or when you move the suitcase all the money gets throw across the room, and the worst, disappearing objects. After three hours of cleaning and burning, I had found all the money and was getting ready to clock out, but I bumped the suitcase, causing it to glitch out and send one of the rolls of bills flying. Luckily, I watched where it landed. Unluckily, I also watched it fall out of the map through the floor. OCD people will love/hate this game, and so will anybody with addictive natures. But I doubt any 'hardcore' Call of Duty players will enjoy this for more than ten minutes. Pros:Lo Wang's witty commentsrevolutionizes cleaningaddictive gameplayinteresting and original mechanics (using incinerator, buckets spilling, Etc.)Cons:it’s a cleaning game... Enough saidbugs, glitches, etc.8/10Curator page:http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6857919/

												Well - as you probably know from other reviews, Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior is a free gift for users who purchase Shadow Warrior, so in this case we can't talk about price-value ratio.This leaves us with enjoyment-time ratio - it was free, but does it worth the time to play?The game is really simple: clean up the temple. You have your trustworthy mop (press 1) your hands, trained on numerous temples you cleaned before (press 2) and "The Sniffer" (press 3) which can detect blood and clutter around you (left click to turn on/off, right click to change mode)The game mechanically both simple and great. You need to clean the place up - get shurikens, katanas, guns and smashed statues to the incinerator, as well as mop up the blood and clean up the severed torsos, limbs, internal organs (Hey, they had a wild party previously!) The little trick is in the later items - bumping into objects, kicking body parts will splatter blood around, and if you step into a blood puddle, you'll leave nice bloodie footprints for a while. You don't need to take every single item to the incinerator - there are yellow crates in which you can dump items, then bring them in one turn. Basically this is the most intresting part of the game.  It's because the game is kinda more physics-simulator than a real game. You can actually throw/put items into the crates, and you can shake them out of it. Tip it over. Collide with a wall and drop it.The game's physics great, and actually somehow the theme also fares really well.  I was mainly playing this when I was too sleepy to play with anything that requires thinking, and actually this was quite a good game for that purpose - I finished it in about 3 hours.Sadly I can't tell anything from the multiplayer options, I haven't tried it out yet.I don't know if there is any point of writing this review as currently the game isn't sold separately but at this point I think I summed the game up quite nicely, maybe some of you will find it useful eventually :)I liked the game, it's really like a good old household chores - while you do the cleaning and menial work, you don't really need to pay attention,  you can think about everything you want. It was a great experience from a free gift game.

												A fun little bonus for any OCD fans of the new Shadow Warrior game.  Sure, Lo Wang can cut a swath through an army of men, but can he clean up after himself?Like many who have played any of the Viscera Cleanup Detail games, I have to say that this game is surprisingly fun for essentially being a housecleaning simulator.  Yeah, on the one hand it's not an adrenaline rush where you feel like a badass for fighting of armies of dudes left and right.  On the other hand though, it's relaxing and pleasant.  Here is a goal, here are your tools, complete as you will.  No time limit, no rush, no one else mucking it up.This particular iteration gets a little bit of a comedic boost by putting you in the shoes of Lo Wang himself, who is none too shy about voicing his opinions on the entire process.  While none of the lines were laugh out loud material, the commentary still brought a smile to my face, making an already enjoyable experience that much better.There are some flaws with this particular version of Viscera Cleanup Detail though.  For one, there are exactly zero instructions available through the game itself.  No way to see controls, no explanation of the objects in the game, no explanation of how to gather money, dispose of remains, or even how to clean your mop.  Most of the game's mechanics I figured out just by poking around, but quite a few I didn't understand until late in my playthrough, things like disposing of items in the Incinerator or how I could get fresh buckets of water from a machine that literally makes buckets of water.  It made me feel a bit cheated in some ways, and certainly undermined a bit of my enjoyment of the game.There is an argument that could be made for game mechanics not being directly explained, since they are relatively simple and not too difficult to figure out.  However, I can really think of no excuse for why there's no way to display the game's controls, much less any way to rebind them.  I will admit that this is not a title where keybindings can make the difference between success and failure, but at the same time the Unreal engine is hardly a difficult engine to add a keybind menu to.  At the very least having an option to display the keybindings would be trivial, and the fact that there's no option to show them is almost unforgivable.  Really, what were the devs thinking?Now, that said, the instructional issues are not a dealbreaker, not for a relatively low-key game such as this.  I still had a surprisingly good time guiding Lo Wang as he cleaned up his own trail of blood, gore, and dismemberment.  As long as you're comfortable with the bog-standard WASD control setup and are willing to look up instructions elsewhere, Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior is a fun little diversion worth spending a few hours on.

'Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior' is an 'unique' game, where you will clean the mess you have created yourself in the main game Shadow Warrior.If you're only interested in the cleaning part without killing I would recommend you to play Viscera Cleanup Detail: Santa's Rampage instead.Desc:You have a wet mop, your hands and a tracing system (like the scanner in Alien) to detect missed blurs or objects. With the mop you will clean the floor/walls/roof from blood. After some blurs the mop will be full of blood and needs to be cleaned, otherwise you will mess up your cleaned placed. There is a station where you can get a new bucket full of fresh water to clean the mop. After some cleanings the water of the bucket will be deep red and needs to be changed too. You have to burn it in a furnace like all other things you will find: cartridge cases, weapons, money and lot of body parts. Your boots will suck full of blood and leave bloody footsteps if you're walking through pools of blood. To finish your cleaning you have to go to a console to check out. The system will inform you about your current progress, if you want to leave and the system is telling you to 'leave the place in shame' then you know you're not done.Pros:+ 'unique' idea for a game+ concept works+ funny comments to certain body partsexample: picking up a heart and he is saying: 'died because of a broken heart' ^^+ funny placed bodiesexample: a person hanging at a wall pierced with a blade will tear apart by picking it up+ no fall damage+ multiplayer(!)Cons:- radio can't be turned on to have music (means no music at all -.-)- less variety in cleaning- only one static level- too few achievements (compared to VCD: Santa's Rampage)- main game will have no effect to the level structureSuggestions:~ add music and cleaning will be more fun~ more achievements (for example 'Lower Ear': Finding the ear of the Boss, 'Gun Connector': Collect all gun types, ..)~ connect the main game with the cleaner (save the slaughter in a DB and load it with the cleaner to have an awesome vice versa gameplay of your own barbarities)Recommended, but only if it's on sale, because it has a short play time and less variety in cleaning.6/10

Like SR, there is a radio you can pick up and carry around if you want some music while you play. The level is also fairly larger than SR, but a lot more symmetrical.Thus far, I have found no way to kill yourself, so I do not think this is possible in SW. 												I booted this one up right after beating the Shadow Warrior campaign for the first time.  I'm familiar with the full Viscera Cleanup Detail and the Santa's Workshop stand-alone, but had yet to play either of those, so I was going into this experience with fresh eyes.  Boy, what an experience it turned out to be.  I had seen the trailers, the screenshots, but actually walking into Zilla's dojo to pick up the mess left by Lo Wang was somehow, as boring as the idea of janitorial labor may sound, so cathartic and entertaining.  I'm not sure if the assets were reused ad-naseum from Shadow Warrior, but this stand alone still looks as gorgeous as the base game.  The new parts added in specifically for VCD have just a vaguely more cartoonish style to them than the rest of the game, but it isn't jarring, and just makes things easier to play as you can easily, visually, distinguish what is part of the map, and what is a tool to help you clean it.  In my playthrough, I spent HOURS scrubbing the hell out of the floor, the walls, and burning any body part, organ, or piece of shrapnel that didn't belong.  The tasks were reptitive, but not in annoying way, it felt a lot more like playing something that keeps you coming back despite staying the same mechanically, like Tetris, than it did actually doing a chore like mowing the lawn or shoveling the sidewalk.  Despite all of this, the punchout machine still gave me flak for not completing the job properly, for someone with severe OCD this could probably be maddening, as I walked around the map for a good ten minutes looking for anything I had forgotten to clean up.  I guess even in the virtual space, perfection isn't easily obtained.  This nice little freebie (yes,it comes free with the base Shadow Warrior purchase) has me sold on the main Viscera Cleanup Detail game, and I'm looking forward to seeing how RuneStorm expands upon the concept for a full-blown title of their own design.

												If you like to play a serious game, then put it away to move on to the next game. This isn't for you.If you like screwing around in a serious game trying to do stuff you really shouldn't do in the real game... this will probably entertain you for some time.If you're OCD, project-oriented, or process-optimization-oriented, then this can turn into crack-cocaine for you.Like all VCD's, you'll either love it or hate it. It sparks a certain user-base while really annoying another. Really not much middle ground.Last time I played Shadow Warrior was in the 90's when it came out after Duke Nukem 3D. I haven't played the updated version. I'm just getting old and bored with "serious" games. But, VCD has caught my interest, and the Shadow Warrior VCD was pretty entertaining.I think my only beef with it is there's no "Office" after-party to show how you did like in the main VCD game. You go to clock out, and it berates you saying there's still cleaning to do. You look all over the place, but it looks clean. You use the sniffer... don't get anything. So, you "clock out in shame" just to get back to the start screen. No telling how well you did.I don't mind a stand-alone game, but I think this should have been tacked onto VCD as a level instead of as a stand-alone game. Modify "The Office" to include trophy showcases for Shadow Warrior stuff. (But, that's an issue with VCD as a whole... The Office is a pretty lackluster trophy showroom.)Overall, had fun. Worth it if you love VCD. Lo Wang's comments were funny at times. However, they really didn't do much to flex the potential of VCD. It was just cleaning as usual. There were no puzzles or secret areas or such to find. Just typical VCD things.

												I rate the very short add-on game Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior 3.5/5. This game is really more of a joke than an actual game but it works, it has no bugs and for a few minutes it was pretty fun......before it became boring and repetitive. Still, I successfully incinerated most of the gibs, left bloody footprints all over the floor in the process but left the job site unfinished (the Zillah corporation can go screw itself) with 1,450,000 dollars I found laying around along with 2 katanas, a submachine gun, a pistol and a human head, all locked neatly in my character's trunk.In this game, you play a janitor tasked with cleaning up the initial scene of the game Shadow Warrior's prologue all from a first-person-perspective. You have a digital device which helps you find messes, a mop and your two gloved hands. With these tools you are to go about cleaning up the numerous pools of blood and scattered body parts from around by mopping the floor with clean water and shoving everything else (including the body parts) into either of the 2 nearby incinerators. Picking stuff up and putting it in the incinerators is the fun part. Every time you pick anything up (including body parts) your character groans, moans or complains or says some dry witticism. Mopping however is intensely boring. It's basically a fairly accurate simulation of mopping a really messy floor (which I why I didn't bother to do it much). You can clock out of the job site early, leaving the job unfinished or, for a single measly Steam Achievement, you can finish the enormous cleaning job. The graphics are good and the sound is adequate. The music comes from a scratchy tinny radio set which you can carry around from place to place to listen to as you work. It plays music from the Shadow Warrior remake. This game is clearly just intended for a few laughs. I mean you could actually take the trouble to complete it, but...if you wanted to do that why not just mop an actual floor for a far more visceral experience and be more useful at the same time? Still, this game might be fun to play simply so you can tell your friends that you actually played it (kind of like playing surgeon simulator).

This game is really more of a joke than an actual game but it works, it has no bugs and for a few minutes it was pretty fun......before it became boring and repetitive. Still, I successfully incinerated most of the gibs, left bloody footprints all over the floor in the process but left the job site unfinished (the Zillah corporation can go screw itself) with 1,450,000 dollars I found laying around along with 2 katanas, a submachine gun, a pistol and a human head, all locked neatly in my character's trunk.In this game, you play a janitor tasked with cleaning up the initial scene of the game Shadow Warrior's prologue all from a first-person-perspective. You have a digital device which helps you find messes, a mop and your two gloved hands. With these tools you are to go about cleaning up the numerous pools of blood and scattered body parts from around by mopping the floor with clean water and shoving everything else (including the body parts) into either of the 2 nearby incinerators. Picking stuff up and putting it in the incinerators is the fun part. Every time you pick anything up (including body parts) your character groans, moans or complains or says some dry witticism. Mopping however is intensely boring. It's basically a fairly accurate simulation of mopping a really messy floor (which I why I didn't bother to do it much). You can clock out of the job site early, leaving the job unfinished or, for a single measly Steam Achievement, you can finish the enormous cleaning job. The graphics are good and the sound is adequate. The music comes from a scratchy tinny radio set which you can carry around from place to place to listen to as you work. It plays music from the Shadow Warrior remake. This game is clearly just intended for a few laughs. I mean you could actually take the trouble to complete it, but...if you wanted to do that why not just mop an actual floor for a far more visceral experience and be more useful at the same time? 												The game comes with Shadow Warrior which is a game that is already worth it's price point with how fun it is but this is one of those games that for some reason held my attention for the whole time I was playing it. I just had to clean up everything. It's oddly entertaining for a game that is basically about janitorial duties. There are a few problems like the fact that all buckets, waste baskets and the money basket are a chore to carry around and sometimes get stuck in the floor causing either you or the object your carrying to be propelled along. It's kind of annoying yet somewhat charming. You pick up limbs and giblets of the enemy combatants in the game Shadow Warrior and have to incinerate them by either carrying them into the waste baskets or just throwing them in yourself. Carrying the small items in your hands like the body parts works much better than the baskets so I just took them individually unless I there was small items on the floor like bullets which I would collect in the baskets. The second part of you job is to mop up blood and this can be made hard because sometimes the blood can be very faded. Luckily there is a tracker which both tells you when your near blood and near body parts depending on which mouse button you click to turn it on. I personally like the fact that the tracker is not just a GPS that leads you to the exact location next bloodstain but instead a object that beeps faster the closer you are. Some may find it annoying in a world where games always tell us where to go even for the secrets but like Shadow Warrior, Viscera Cleanup Deatail has a feeling of less hand holding even while in an area that is less open than most games. For achievements there is of course the achievement for cleaning up the whole place and the achievement for getting all the hidden money in the game. There are 20 stacks of cash in the game that are usually in piles of body parts that you must put in a cash box iin order to unlock the achievement. While both of these achievements seem missable they are actually very easy to track. Just go to the door that has the device that asks you if you want to leave and push the button to activate and to leave. It will then tell you how much money you have and whether the rooms are all clear. If it says you have less than 2 million dollars and you left the room unclean than you simply push the button that you actually want to stay. Then just go through the rooms again once with the giblets tracker and then again with the blood tracker to find what you have missed. It's actually a very simple yet oddly entertaining game. For a free add-on to a game that I would say is worth it's price point it is an oddly entertaining experience that I oddly wrote a lot about in this review. You don't need to pick up Shadow Warrior to play this game but I highly suggest it since Shadow Warrior itself is a refreshing and gory FPS that actually has a fun sword mechanic.

The Physics can be a pain to deal with, making it hard to get items into buckets or furnaces, gibs flying around during clean up to make your job harder, and the worst are objects or blood spatters that end up in such awkward locations that you need to resort to cheating to find them. The devs should find a way to mitigate this necessity. That said this stupid but enjoyable experience can be finished in about an hour or two and while the game has an intentionally annoying factor to it, it feels strangely satisfying to do something so mundane in a video game world. I definitely recommend playing this or Santa's Rampage for some laughs.

Swords, guns, ninja stars and punchy one-linersViscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior is a 1 hour level themed about the newer Shadow Warrior game released in 2013. Though I never played Shadow Warrior I say others play it and it’s your typical Hack and Slash shoot em' up type of deal with lots of one-liners, loads of guys with swords, guns and excessive amounts of blood. How is this relevant to this game you might be wondering? Well it was produced as a Pre-Order Bonus for buying Shadow Warrior back when it released then given to Viscera Cleanup Detail buyers as well which as a fan of the game I great for us to get a little more content out of the game like they did with Santa's Rampage. Only this time there is only 2 achievements, both of which are very easy to get and leaves you with the rewarding 100% completion if you've completed the level and collected all the cash. The level itself is pretty simple, 2 large rooms with small connecting corridors connecting them as well as stairs to the upper part of each room which only have a little to clean up. Majority of the mess is in the large room and they provide you with 2 furnaces, 1 in each room so you don't have to keep running back which is nice!The cleaner takes the role as if he is connected to the Shadow Warrior game with one-liners such as "Hey, I know this guy... Who's laughing now!" when you pick up a head or "I hope these gloves are thick enough" when you pick up glass shards etc. This makes the level really stand out from the others and adds a little fun to the mix. He does whistle every now and then which get annoying because of the high pitch but its fine. 8/10Enjoyable 1 hour map, funny dialogue and easy 100% achievements
